text: hi I'm Bob global identity leader with
IBM and today's topic is to look at how
I AWS and IBM work together to address
the number one issue in cyber security
today The number one issue in cyber
security is that 80% of all attacks
right now are focused on identities both
human and nonhuman identities and their
access to systems The problem comes from
the fact that the way people manage
identities today is all over the place
And so let me show you what I mean by
that So when we go and have a
conversation about identities with a
client we usually end up talking about
two different kinds of identities Our
workforce users like our employees and
partners and then we have our consumers
or in public sector to the citizens that
are logging in to get access to public
services and things like that On top of
that we also have non-human identities
such as the applications that are
modernized dev sec ops applications that
are connecting to each other The issue
that exists out there today is you'd
assume that people would use a
consistent way to manage those
identities But the truth is when I go
and ask a client what is your strategy
for identity management They typically
will answer me with the name of a tool
And I'll say that's a that's a tool
That's actually not a strategy and
they'll say "Well but we've got this
tool and we want everybody to use it."
And then I ask the simp the obvious
question right which is do you think
everyone will use the tool And then
people look at the floor And the reason
is most organizations have a separate
identity and access management system
for managing their consumers from their
workforce and in their workforce often
times they'll have a system that they
wrote 20 25 years ago that's still
supporting a bunch of legacy
applications that also sometimes you
manage the identities in those
separately and then of course as soon as
you modernize to the cloud such as with
AWS you're going to be managing
identities there as well So if you think
about it the problem is that these red
dots represent all the different places
and this is a very simplified view of it
where we have different groups of people
that are saying here is a security
policy with the types of users we have
and what access they should have but
we're managing it with different groups
of people in lots of different places So
what has happened in the industry is
then there's been a realization that
this very spread out way of managing
identities is what's leading to
identities being such an a visible
attack vector today Now the fact that
it's ugly is okay big deal What's the
real problem The real problem is that
the things people are trying to do to
become more secure with their online
presence is impossible with the current
rate and pace For example frictionless
access Today when you're relying on
business growth through modernized
applications um what you want to do is
reduce the friction Meaning every time
you have to enter your password or look
it up probably right and enter your
password that's a form of friction When
you get a six-digit code sent to your
device and you have to plug it in that's
a form of friction There are the ability
to do frictionless authentication
passwordless literally eliminating
passwords that are more secure than the
current state And yet how do you
implement frictionless authentication
across all of these different places
identities are being managed You cannot
It's impossible Secondly as I said 80%
of all the attacks are on identity So
threat management is a huge topic It's
clear that the way that we're doing that
today typically through a SIM tool in
the security operations center with the
user behavior analytics module is not
working that well So there's been two
new AI based radical developments in our
industry One is ITDR identity threat
detection response The other is identity
security posture management or ISPM That
is the ability to see policy bypasses
such as a multiffactor authentication
policy bypass as it's happening That's
the ITDR side of things Then the ISPM
side of things is where do you see
sloppy identity posture rolled out where
hackers can easily take advantage of
that such as having shadow users and
shadow assets and shadow directories and
shadow access All of that is brand new
AI based technologies that are out there
that allow us to address this issue of
80% of the attacks being on identities
Third this one is amazing to think about
An auditor will show up in an
organization and say with all your
different systems that you have here
show me a consolidated view of who has
access to my systems and what access do
they have Nobody can do it today because
it's literally being managed in all
these different places So the need to be
able to show a consolidated view has
become a huge issue And the final one
this is kind of fun is cyber insurance
Cyber insurance providers clearly want
to make sure that the organizations that
they're providing their policies to have
at least baseline security policies in
place What cyber insurance providers
have figured out is that almost
everybody has a hole on one of the most
important pieces and that is privileged
access management or Pam as people call
it These are the most privileged users
They can do things in your systems and
then go into the audit logs and remove
the entries they ever did anything It's
not we don't trust our employees Is that
because identity is a number one attack
vector When you have a compromised valid
credential that is a privileged user it
becomes a huge issue So cyber insurance
providers universally now are asking
organizations do you know where all your
privileged users are and do you have
proper PAM controls against them And the
truth is almost nobody does Everybody's
got PAM but it's usually only rolled out
to a fraction of the privileged users
And so having privilege access
management across the board has become a
huge topic These are just four of dozens
of things that people would like to do
to become more secure But because of
that mess of how identities are being
managed today it's been impossible So
what IBM and AWS collaborate on is how
do we form an identity fabric How do I
take all these different places where
I'm managing identities and get it to
work together into a nice fabric that
actually collaborates Well what we found
is that there's seven components of
being able to do this The first is the
ability to do identity orchestration The
ability to do something like a user
logging into a legacy application that
doesn't even support multiffactor
authentication and through identity
orchestration not only allowing it to
support MFA but also
passwordless eliminate passwords That's
very critical and IBM and AWS do that
across our platforms Second is riskbased
authentication That's an AI based
behavioral analytics capability that
when someone logs into a compromised
valid credential you can actually
discover it as it's happening because
the behavior of the user logging in such
as typing rate on their keyboard and the
error rate in their typing doesn't match
the first 243 times that the actual real
user logged in You can detect stuff like
that The reason that's so critical is
that our cost of data breach study last
year discovered that for an identity
based attack the average number of days
it takes to identify and contain the
attack is literally 292 days When you
use AI based behavioral analytics the
first time the hacker logs into the
compromised account you can tell it's
not the right person and you can chop it
off at the beginning That's the second
piece is riskbased authentication Third
is legacy applications A lot of these
legacy applications you don't even have
the people around anymore that wrote
them And so how can you possibly add
multiffactor authentication frictionless
authentication etc to them Well there
are ways now to do low code no code
integration And we in AWS provide that
together Fourth is governance You need
to be able to set up manage and
eliminate accounts in a consistent way
People today generally call that joiner
mover lever And doing that consistently
across all the platforms is critical
Fifth is directory synchronization where
you get a consolidated view to address
that single view problem I mentioned
ITDR and ISPM a lot of people are
calling those things identity
observability is kind of the short term
that's being used for that and that's
once again being able to find attacks on
the identities in real time such as
policy bypasses as well as poor security
posture identity posture they can be
taken advantage of That's the ISPM piece
Those two together are called identity
observability And then uh finally is
privilege access management of course
need to be able to do that So IBM and
AWS collaborate to be able to provide
this into an AI fused identity fabric So
the core use cases of what we focus on
here is that first of all the ability to
do eliminating passwords passwordless
frictionless whatever term you want to
use We provide that through our verify
IBM verify platform today Uh for clients
that don't have the IBM verify platform
that are using another tool such as octa
ping whatever um we have the verify
application gateway that provides that
ability to do do low code no code access
into those legacy applications for
nonIBM identity providers Secondly using
AI to find the policy bypasses to find
the poor posture and to find the
behavioral analytics that can catch
something live like I was just sharing
that is done through our IBM verify
platform Once again for clients that
have octa ping or some other identity
provider our verify trust product
provides that same functionality Um next
is actually delivering the overall
governance of truly forming this
identity fabric across AWS and IBM that
is provided by our verify platform
Fourth that whole ITDR ISPM identity
observability piece I shared is a very
special case It is an AI engine that
pulls in all the network flows all the
cloud flows and all the identity
activity So it sees what's actually
happening not what do you think's
happening but what's really happening
and it finds those policy bypasses It
finds the misconfigurations It finds the
shadow directories and access and
application access etc And that's done
through our verify identity uh
protection solution And then finally for
the privilege access management we have
our verify privilege identity that
allows you to easily expand the PAM
controls to all of the privileged
accounts that are out there And then
finally we're really excited at IBM
because we just completed our
acquisition of Hashi Corp And Hashi
Cororp is not only the industry leader
in doing infrastructure life cycle
management through Terraform and some of
the other tools there but also Hashi
Corp is the industry leader in security
life cycle manager management for
modernized applications especially
through Hashi Cororp vault and boundary
the ability to do secrets management in
a much more secure way across the entire
application stack And so the combination
of IBM verify for identity management
and hashy corp vault and boundary for
applying secrets management and remote
access against all this allows us
uniquely with AWS for the first time to
pull the enterprise IT teams that are
often focused on human identities and
the modern DevOps and dev secc ops team
on the platform engineering teams that
are doing a lot of modernized apps with
non-human identities We're now able to
pull all that into the fabric So we can
provide an identity fabric that handles
human identities non-human identities
secrets management full and identity
access management and a single stack
Okay So you I hope you've seen here this
is very exciting stuff Most of the
attacks are taking on taking place in
this vector and the fact that AWS and
IBM work together we host a lot of our
stuff on AWS and that we can truly
address the number one attack vector in
cyber today Thanks for your time
